ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] https for WebUI?
ygData.msgSnippet: HTTPS support is coming in a future heritrix-2 release; an initial implementation exists in our heritrix2 source tree. The related issue is:

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] https for WebUI?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=B6AOCVDm54oABK-gCXmDjYzOjVWnwYZWl3DHbalg8lnT
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

HTTPS support is coming in a future heritrix-2 release; an initial 
implementation exists in our heritrix2 source tree. The related issue is:

http://webteam.archive.org/jira/browse/HER-1038

When in place, operators will have to provide your own server-side 
signing certificate, so in practice this will typically be a homemade, 
self-signed certificate (which we will help Heritrix operators create if 
necessary).

Accessing the HTTPS admin interface would thus mean adding an exception 
to your desktop browser, and full vigilance would mean manually 
verifying the certificate matches what you expect at the time of 
accepting this exception. Even without full vigilance, however, this 
would protect against casual/passive eavesdropping of the operator web 
traffic.

In the meantime for Heritrix 1.14.x:

I'm guessing that the direct host:port of the Heritrix machine is 
blocked for your desktop PCs, because the organization does not want 
normal, unencrypted HTTP traffic (including the Heritrix operator 
password) traveling over the network from the desktop the Heritrix machine.

As a result, you're required to run the web browser on a remote trusted 
machine that is near (or possibly the same as) the machine running 
Heritrix. (Its link to Heritrix is short and trusted for unencrypted 
traffic.) You bring the X interface of that browser up on your desktop 
via a secure X connection. The result is slow/awkward interactions with 
the Heritrix web UI. Is that an accurate guess?

Some alternatives that might work in the same environment, and be 
equivalently secure with less awkwardness than the X application 
approach, include:

- Set up an SSH tunnel from your desktop to the 'trusted' machine that 
can trivially reach Heritrix. Essentially, you'd then point your browser 
at http://localhost:12345/, which would go over the SSH tunnel to the 
trusted machine, which would continue the normal connection to Heritrix. 
If your desktop has SSH and you have an account on the trusted machine 
-- which is likely in the X scenario -- it's just a matter of the right 
SS invocation for your environment.

- Have an existing HTTPS server forward part of its URL space to the 
Heritrix instance(s). This might only be a few lines of configuration on 
an existing Apache already set up with HTTPS -- mod_rewrite proxy rule(s).

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA

grahlaura wrote:
> Because Heritrix WebUI is over http instead of https our institution
> is requiring us to use X server apps (Xming) on our PCs for access,
> which in turn has a negative impact on navigation.
> 
> Any chance of implementing https in a future release???
> 
> Thanks.
> 
> Laura Graham
> Library of Congress
